docs.lead_paragraph: The application of advanced radiological and genetic techniques to Egyptian mummies is a new step in the reach of historical inquiry through science.

headline.main: Malaria Is a Likely Killer in King Tut’s Post-Mortem
headline.print_headline: Malaria Most Likely Killed King Tut, Scientists Say

docs.snippet: The application of advanced radiological and genetic techniques to Egyptian mummies is a new step in the reach of historical inquiry through science.

docs.lead_paragraph: King Tutankhamen, the boy pharaoh, was frail and lame and suffered ''multiple disorders'' when he died at age 19 about 1324 B.C., but scientists have now determined the most likely agents of death: a severe bout of malaria combined with a degenerative bone condition. The researchers said that to their knowledge ''this is the oldest genetic proof of malaria in precisely dated mummies.'' Several other mummies in the study also showed DNA evidence of the presence of the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum, perhaps not surprising in a place like the Nile Valley.

headline.main: Malaria Is a Likely Killer In King Tut's Post-Mortem

docs.abstract: Scientists using DNA evidence have determined that King Tutankhamen probably died of malaria combined with degenerative bone condition; several other mummies in study also show presence of malaria; application of advanced radiological and genetic techniques to royal Egyptian mummies is new step in each of historical inquiry through science; research was directed by Zahi Hawass, leader of Supreme Council of antiquities in Cairo; photo (M)
